post: Dan cited my paper above, Hugh’s question is valid and I can answer for myself. We do not know when exactly rigor mortis set in, since this process takes about two hours to start and goes on till there is complete postmortem stiffness. It is clear that the man who used the cloth to cover Jesus’ face was concerned with restraining the blood coming from the nose and the right hand side of the mouth (see the larger illustrations in the paper, particularly the face image). He may therefore not have thought it necessary to wrap the cloth around the head. What he may have done was to fold the cloth so that it would become more thick and thus more pressure could be applied. It would be more effective. It is a possibility. There is no general agreement about how the cloth was used on the face, not even in Spain. The pathologist and coroner I mentioned has limited information. Whatever, it is evident that this does not affect the perfect model produced by the professor of sculpture..

post: The impression one gets is that Turin does not take seriously any of the proposals presented to explain why the 1988 radiocarbon dating results may have been skewed. That is in fact sort of echoed in Ian Wilson’s last Shroud book. We now know that Turin has brushed aside the proposals and the attention is focused on radiocarbon dating but, even then, they are hesitant to go forward. The reason can be read in the last q/r: https://www.academia.edu/11355553/Dr. Paolo Di Lazzaro explains his research on image formation on the Shroud of Turin With the recent Vatileaks scandals one notices that there is no lack of traitors, clerics included. Now, when it comes to dating ancient textiles, although the Masada excavation is still the object of controversy despite the good intentions of Y. Yadin, we at least know that the cloths found there were dated to AD 70. For more, the cloths used to wrap the Dead Sea Scrolls were also correctly dated. Note: By Willard Libby himself, around 1950. The results he obtained matched the studies made by Father Roland de Vaux. Who excavated Qumran and was the first editor in chief of the Dead Sea Srolls. Radiocarbon dating is an important tool in deciding chronology in biblical archaeology and micro archaeology will not change the picture. It is used together with C14: https://www.academia.edu/18994343/The key role of Biblical Archaeology in Exegesis An Interview with Professor Israel Finkelstein That is why the questions in the thread “SSG member wants to know” are important. They may be one among other leads..
